channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Bitter taste receptors are even older than scientists thought
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01031-6

Discovery in sharks suggests that these sensory receptors date back to some 450 million years ago.
item.dc:title: Bitter taste receptors are even older than scientists thought

item.title: An exoplanet is wrapped in glory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01032-5

Astronomers spot the first planet outside the Solar System to boast a phenomenon reminiscent of a rainbow.
item.dc:title: An exoplanet is wrapped in glory

item.title: Biological age surges in survivors of childhood cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01033-4

People who survived paediatric cancers age faster and are at higher risk of early death.
item.dc:title: Biological age surges in survivors of childhood cancer

item.title: Scientists discover first algae that can fix nitrogen — thanks to a tiny cell structure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01046-z

A newly discovered ‘organelle’ that converts nitrogen gas into a useful form could pave the way for engineered plants that require less fertilizer.
item.dc:title: Scientists discover first algae that can fix nitrogen — thanks to a tiny cell structure
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: This fMRI technique promised to transform brain research — why can no one replicate it?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00931-x

The DIANA technique sparked excitement from neuroscientists. But two new papers have cast doubt over the results.
item.dc:title: This fMRI technique promised to transform brain research — why can no one replicate it?
item.dc:creator: McKenzie Prillaman

item.title: Selenium alloyed tellurium oxide for amorphous p-channel transistors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07360-w

Selenium alloyed tellurium oxide for amorphous p-channel transistors
item.dc:title: Selenium alloyed tellurium oxide for amorphous p-channel transistors
item.dc:creator: Ao Liu
Yong-Sung Kim

item.title: ROS-dependent S-palmitoylation activates cleaved and intact gasdermin D
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07373-5

ROS-dependent S-palmitoylation activates cleaved and intact gasdermin D
item.dc:title: ROS-dependent S-palmitoylation activates cleaved and intact gasdermin D

item.title: Randomness in computation wins computer-science ‘Nobel’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01055-y

Computer scientist Avi Wigderson is known for clarifying the role of randomness in algorithms, and for studying their complexity.
item.dc:title: Randomness in computation wins computer-science ‘Nobel’
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: The ‘ghost roads’ driving tropical deforestation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01070-z

Researchers find that a huge number of roads that don’t appear on official maps, and the protein that could determine whether someone is left-handed.
item.dc:title: The ‘ghost roads’ driving tropical deforestation
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Ghost roads and the destruction of Asia-Pacific tropical forests
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07303-5

An effort to map roads in the Asia-Pacific region finds that there are 3.0–6.6 times more roads than other sources suggest, and that unmapped ‘ghost roads’ are a major contributor to tropical forest loss.
item.dc:title: Ghost roads and the destruction of Asia-Pacific tropical forests
item.dc:creator: Jayden E. Engert
Mason J. Campbell
Joshua E. Cinner
Yoko Ishida
Sean Sloan
Jatna Supriatna
Mohammed Alamgir
Jaime Cislowski
William F. Laurance

item.title: Force-controlled release of small molecules with a rotaxane actuator
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07154-0

A rotaxane-based mechanochemical system enables force-controlled release of multiple cargo molecules that are appended to its molecular axle.
item.dc:title: Force-controlled release of small molecules with a rotaxane actuator
item.dc:creator: Lei Chen
Robert Nixon
Guillaume De Bo

item.title: Sex differences orchestrated by androgens at single-cell resolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07291-6

The effects of sex and androgens on the molecular programs and cellular populations are explored using a single-cell transcriptomic atlas comprising over 2.3 million cells from different tissues in Mus musculus.
item.dc:title: Sex differences orchestrated by androgens at single-cell resolution
item.dc:creator: Fei Li
Xudong Xing

item.title: Emergence of fractal geometries in the evolution of a metabolic enzyme
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07287-2

Citrate synthase from the cyanobacterium Synechococcus elongatus is shown to self-assemble into Sierpiński triangles, a finding that opens up the possibility that other naturally occurring molecular-scale fractals exist.
item.dc:title: Emergence of fractal geometries in the evolution of a metabolic enzyme
item.dc:creator: Franziska L. Sendker

item.title: FOXO1 enhances CAR T cell stemness, metabolic fitness and efficacy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07242-1

Increased effectiveness of anti-cancer chimeric antigen receptor T cell therapy is associated with a stem-like phenotype through increased expression of FOXO1.
item.dc:title: FOXO1 enhances CAR T cell stemness, metabolic fitness and efficacy
item.dc:creator: Jack D. Chan

item.title: Mid-ocean ridge unfaulting revealed by magmatic intrusions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07247-w

Recent sequences of reverse-faulting earthquakes at the Mid-Atlantic Ridge and the Carlsberg Ridge show that tectonic extension at mid-ocean ridge axes can be partially undone by tectonic shortening across the ridge flanks.
item.dc:title: Mid-ocean ridge unfaulting revealed by magmatic intrusions
item.dc:creator: Jean-Arthur Olive
Göran Ekström
W. Roger Buck
Zhonglan Liu
Javier Escartín
Manon Bickert

item.title: Metabolic rewiring promotes anti-inflammatory effects of glucocorticoids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07282-7

Glucocorticoids reprogram the mitochondrial metabolism of macrophages, resulting in increased and sustained production of the anti-inflammatory metabolite itaconate and, as a consequence, inhibition of the inflammatory response.
item.dc:title: Metabolic rewiring promotes anti-inflammatory effects of glucocorticoids
item.dc:creator: Jean-Philippe Auger

item.title: Cell-type-resolved mosaicism reveals clonal dynamics of the human forebrain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07292-5

Using mosaic variant barcode analysis, clonal dynamics of specific cell types are deconvolved in the human forebrain.
item.dc:title: Cell-type-resolved mosaicism reveals clonal dynamics of the human forebrain
item.dc:creator: Changuk Chung

item.title: Phononic switching of magnetization by the ultrafast Barnett effect
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07200-x

Ultrafast light-induced driving of phonons at resonance in a substrate facilitates the permanent reversal of the magnetic state of a material mounted on it.
item.dc:title: Phononic switching of magnetization by the ultrafast Barnett effect
item.dc:creator: C. S. Davies
F. G. N. Fennema
A. Tsukamoto
I. Razdolski
A. V. Kimel
A. Kirilyuk

item.title: Distal colonocytes targeted by C. rodentium recruit T-cell help for barrier defence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07288-1

The murine enteropathogen Citrobacter rodentium targets a specific subset of absorptive intestinal epithelial cells in the mid–distal colon, which stimulate T cells to produce sustained IL-22 signals to mitigate further spread of the pathogen.
item.dc:title: Distal colonocytes targeted by C. rodentium recruit T-cell help for barrier defence
item.dc:creator: Carlene L. Zindl
C. Garrett Wilson
Awalpreet S. Chadha
Lennard W. Duck
Baiyi Cai
Stacey N. Harbour
Yoshiko Nagaoka-Kamata
Robin D. Hatton
Min Gao
David A. Figge
Casey T. Weaver

item.title: FSC-certified forest management benefits large mammals compared to non-FSC
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07257-8

Camera-trap images of 55 mammal species in 14 logging concessions in western equatorial Africa reveal greater animal encounter rates in FSC-certified than in non-certified forests, especially for large mammals and species of high conservation priority.
item.dc:title: FSC-certified forest management benefits large mammals compared to non-FSC
item.dc:creator: Joeri A. Zwerts
E. H. M. Sterck
Pita A. Verweij
Fiona Maisels
Jaap van der Waarde
Emma A. M. Geelen
Georges Belmond Tchoumba
Hermann Frankie Donfouet Zebaze
Marijke van Kuijk

item.title: Ligand efficacy modulates conformational dynamics of the µ-opioid receptor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07295-2

Studies on the µ-opioid receptor using fluorescent labelling of intracellular residues and energy transfer experiments in the presence of different ligands with or without G-protein binding reveals conformational changes that correlate to ligand efficacy.
item.dc:title: Ligand efficacy modulates conformational dynamics of the µ-opioid receptor
item.dc:creator: Jiawei Zhao
Matthias Elgeti
Evan S. O’Brien
Cecília P. Sár
Amal EI Daibani

Chunlai Chen

item.title: Direct observation of a magnetic-field-induced Wigner crystal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07212-7

A magnetic-field-induced Wigner crystal in Bernal-stacked bilayer graphene was directly imaged using high-resolution scanning tunnelling microscopy and its structural properties as a function of electron density, magnetic field and temperature were examined.
item.dc:title: Direct observation of a magnetic-field-induced Wigner crystal
item.dc:creator: Yen-Chen Tsui
Minhao He
Yuwen Hu
Ethan Lake
Taige Wang
Kenji Watanabe
Takashi Taniguchi
Michael P. Zaletel
Ali Yazdani

item.title: A hybrid topological quantum state in an elemental solid
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07203-8

A hybrid topological phase of matter is discovered in the simple elemental-solid arsenic and explored using tunnelling microscopy, photoemission spectroscopy and a theoretical analysis.
item.dc:title: A hybrid topological quantum state in an elemental solid
item.dc:creator: Md Shafayat Hossain
Frank Schindler

item.title: Terahertz electric-field-driven dynamical multiferroicity in SrTiO<sub>3</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07175-9

We demonstrate the emergence of magnetism induced by a terahertz electric field in SrTiO3.
item.dc:title: Terahertz electric-field-driven dynamical multiferroicity in SrTiO<sub>3</sub>
item.dc:creator: M. Basini
M. Pancaldi
B. Wehinger

S. Bonetti

item.title: Bitter taste receptor activation by cholesterol and an intracellular tastant
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07253-y

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of the type 2 taste receptor TAS2R14 in complex with Ggust and Gi1 identify cholesterol as an orthosteric agonist and the bitter tastant cmpd28.1 as a positive allosteric modulator and agonist.
item.dc:title: Bitter taste receptor activation by cholesterol and an intracellular tastant
item.dc:creator: Yoojoong Kim
Ryan H. Gumpper
Yongfeng Liu
D. Dewran Kocak
Yan Xiong

Shicheng Zhang
Jian Jin
Bryan L. Roth

item.title: Necroptosis blockade prevents lung injury in severe influenza
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07265-8

A newly developed RIPK3 inhibitor blocks necroptosis of lung cells, reduces lung inflammation and prevents mortality in a mouse model of influenza A virus infection.
item.dc:title: Necroptosis blockade prevents lung injury in severe influenza
item.dc:creator: Avishekh Gautam

item.title: FOXO1 is a master regulator of memory programming in CAR T cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07300-8

The transcription factor FOXO1 has a key role in human T cell memory, and manipulating FOXO1 expression could provide a way to enhance CAR T cell therapies by increasing CAR T cell persistence and antitumour activity.
item.dc:title: FOXO1 is a master regulator of memory programming in CAR T cells
item.dc:creator: Alexander E. Doan

item.title: Peter Higgs: science mourns giant of particle physics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01069-6

The British physicist, who has died aged 94, predicted the existence of the Higgs boson in the 1960s.
item.dc:title: Peter Higgs: science mourns giant of particle physics
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: How to supercharge cancer-fighting cells: give them stem-cell skills
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01043-2

The bioengineered immune players called CAR T cells last longer and work better if pumped up with a large dose of a protein that makes them resemble stem cells.
item.dc:title: How to supercharge cancer-fighting cells: give them stem-cell skills
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Frans de Waal (1948–2024), primatologist who questioned the uniqueness of human minds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01071-y

Researcher and prolific science communicator who laid bare the social lives of apes.
item.dc:title: Frans de Waal (1948–2024), primatologist who questioned the uniqueness of human minds
item.dc:creator: Andrew Whiten

item.title: What happens when climate change and the mental-health crisis collide?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00993-x

The warming planet is worsening mental illness and distress. Researchers need to work out the scale of the problem and how those who need assistance can be helped.
item.dc:title: What happens when climate change and the mental-health crisis collide?

item.title: The rise of eco-anxiety: scientists wake up to the mental-health toll of climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00998-6

Researchers want to unpick how climate change affects mental health around the world — from lives that are disrupted by catastrophic weather to people who are anxious about the future.
item.dc:title: The rise of eco-anxiety: scientists wake up to the mental-health toll of climate change
item.dc:creator: Helen Pearson

item.title: Wildlife boost in African forests certified for sustainable logging
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00878-z

Is there a conservation benefit if tropical forests that are affected by logging gain certification from the Forest Stewardship Council? An analysis of the biodiversity outcomes in such tropical forests provides answers.
item.dc:title: Wildlife boost in African forests certified for sustainable logging
item.dc:creator: Julia E. Fa

item.title: India is booming — but there are worries ahead for basic science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00956-2

With voting about to start in India’s general election, some researchers are concerned that sluggish funding growth and slow decision-making processes could hold the country back.
item.dc:title: India is booming — but there are worries ahead for basic science
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Scalable, high-quality 2D telluride nanosheets for energy and catalysis applications
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01006-7

An innovative solid-state lithiation strategy allows the exfoliation of layered transition-metal tellurides into nanosheets in an unprecedentedly short time, without sacrificing their quality. The observation of physical phenomena typically seen in highly crystalline TMT nanosheets opens the way to their use in applications such as batteries and micro-supercapacitors.
item.dc:title: Scalable, high-quality 2D telluride nanosheets for energy and catalysis applications

item.title: Nanoscale scythe cuts molecular tethers using mechanical forces
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00909-9

Nanoscale systems that release small molecules have potential therapeutic and industrial uses, but can result in low numbers of molecules reaching their target. A release system triggered by mechanical force offers a fresh approach.
item.dc:title: Nanoscale scythe cuts molecular tethers using mechanical forces
item.dc:creator: Iwona Nierengarten

item.title: Daily briefing: science mourns physicist Peter Higgs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01077-6

Nature editors remember and celebrate the life of Peter Higgs, the theorist behind the Higgs boson, who died on Monday, aged 94. Also, Iran releases jailed conservationists and a Javan tiger that might not be extinct.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: science mourns physicist Peter Higgs
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Is ChatGPT corrupting peer review? Telltale words hint at AI use
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01051-2

A study of review reports identifies dozens of adjectives that could indicate text written with the help of chatbots.
item.dc:title: Is ChatGPT corrupting peer review? Telltale words hint at AI use
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: Controlling single polyatomic molecules in an optical array for quantum applications
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01009-4

Applications from quantum computing to searches for physics beyond the standard model could benefit from precision control of polyatomic molecules. A method of confining and manipulating single polyatomic molecules held in tightly focused ‘optical tweezer’ laser arrays at ultracold temperatures could boost progress on all those fronts.
item.dc:title: Controlling single polyatomic molecules in an optical array for quantum applications

item.title: Genetic risk variants lead to type 2 diabetes development through different pathways
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00440-x

The largest genome-wide association study for type 2 diabetes so far, which included several ancestry groups, led to the identification of eight clusters of genetic risk variants. The clusters capture different biological pathways that contribute to the disease, and some clusters are associated with vascular complications.
item.dc:title: Genetic risk variants lead to type 2 diabetes development through different pathways

item.title: Three possible muses
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00921-z

Collapse into now.
item.dc:title: Three possible muses
item.dc:creator: Matt Tighe

item.title: Total solar eclipse 2024: what dazzled scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01054-z

Amateur and professional astronomers share with Nature what they observed and what data they collected when the Moon blocked the Sun.
item.dc:title: Total solar eclipse 2024: what dazzled scientists
item.dc:creator: Sumeet Kulkarni
Lauren Wolf

item.title: Light makes atoms behave like electromagnetic coils
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00889-w

Microscopic magnetic fields form in non-magnetic materials when light makes the atoms rotate. A similar macroscopic effect has long been known, but proof of its atomic equivalent could give rise to ultrafast data processing.
item.dc:title: Light makes atoms behave like electromagnetic coils
item.dc:creator: Carl P. Romao
Dominik M. Juraschek

item.title: Blocking cell death limits lung damage and inflammation from influenza
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00910-2

Animals that receive an inhibitor of an antiviral cell-death response called necroptosis are less likely to die of influenza even at a late stage of infection. This has implications for the development of therapies for respiratory diseases.
item.dc:title: Blocking cell death limits lung damage and inflammation from influenza
item.dc:creator: Nishma Gupta
John Silke

item.title: A bitter taste receptor activated in a surprising way
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00712-6

The sensing of bitter taste results from the complex interplay of many chemical cues and a range of receptors. It emerges that this complexity might be built-in even at the level of individual receptors.
item.dc:title: A bitter taste receptor activated in a surprising way
item.dc:creator: Antonella Di Pizio

item.title: Giant energy storage and power density negative capacitance superlattices
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07365-5

Giant energy storage and power density negative capacitance superlattices
item.dc:title: Giant energy storage and power density negative capacitance superlattices
item.dc:creator: Suraj S. Cheema
Nirmaan Shanker
Shang-Lin Hsu
Joseph Schaadt
Nathan M. Ellis
Matthew Cook
Ravi Rastogi

item.title: The comings and goings of ants: how are social skills shaped in an ever-changing world?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01000-z

A colourful study of the natural history of ants that takes in dry deserts and lush forests aims to show that sociality is shaped by, and changes with, the environment.
item.dc:title: The comings and goings of ants: how are social skills shaped in an ever-changing world?

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00995-9

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01053-0

item.dc:title: How I harnessed media engagement to supercharge my research career
item.dc:creator: Ben Singh

item.title: AI can help to tailor drugs for Africa — but Africans should lead the way
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01001-y

Computational models that require very little data could transform biomedical and drug development research in Africa, as long as infrastructure, trained staff and secure databases are available.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01061-0

Enormous loops of plasma erupting from the Sun’s surface became visible as red dots during the total eclipse. Plus, genetic analysis confirms that Blackfoot people belong to an ancient ice age lineage.

item.content:encoded:

item.title: Concurrent inhibition of oncogenic and wild-type RAS-GTP for cancer therapy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07205-6

RMC-7977, a compound that exhibits potent inhibition of the active states of mutant and wild-type KRAS, NRAS and HRAS variants has a strong anti-tumour effect on RAS-addicted tumours and is well tolerated in preclinical models.

item.content:encoded:

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01058-9

An official investigation reveals the extent of superconductivity physicist Ranga Dias’s scientific misconduct. Plus, why scientists are concerned about a bird flu outbreak in US cows and the theory of ‘survival of the nicest’.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: How a physicist faked blockbuster superconductivity claims
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Survival of the nicest: have we got evolution the wrong way round?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00999-5

How humans, animals and even single-celled organisms cooperate to survive suggests there’s more to life than just competition, argues a cheering study of evolutionary biology.
item.dc:title: Survival of the nicest: have we got evolution the wrong way round?
item.dc:creator: Jonathan R. Goodman

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01035-2

item.dc:title: Brazil budget cuts could leave science labs without power and water

item.title: Three ways ChatGPT helps me in my academic writing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01042-3

Generative AI can be a valuable aid in writing, editing and peer review – if you use it responsibly, says Dritjon Gruda.
item.dc:title: Three ways ChatGPT helps me in my academic writing
item.dc:creator: Dritjon Gruda

item.title: How two PhD students overcame the odds to snag tenure-track jobs
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Ready or not, AI is coming to science education — and students have opinions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01002-x

As educators debate whether it’s even possible to use AI safely in research and education, students are taking a role in shaping its responsible use.
item.dc:title: Ready or not, AI is coming to science education — and students have opinions
